catalog.title: Computational Physics 2
catalog.description: More advanced numerical techniques applied to time-independent and time-dependent problems described by linear and nonlinear partial differential equations, and to the physics of systems with many degrees of freedom. Matrix operations and solution of large systems of linear equations. Random variables, importance sampling, and Monte Carlo methods. Visualization of large data sets, and animated computer graphics. Use of mathematical library routines in numerical analysis. Introduction to computer algebra and symbol manipulation programs.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Quantum Theory of Fields
catalog.description: Brief review of classical field theory; discrete and continuous symmetries, conservation laws, and Noether's theorem; canonical quantization of the free Klein-Gordon, Dirac, and electromagnetic fields; path integral quantization; interacting fields and covariant perturbation theory; quantization of Yang-Mills theories; Feynman diagrams; higher-order calculations, ultra-violet and infrared divergences, factorization theorems, regularization, and renormalization; renormalization group and asymptotic behavior; spontaneous symmetry breaking; global and local symmetries and modern gauge theory of elementary particles and their interactions; the standard SU(3)xSU(2)xU(1) model of particle physics, electroweak unification and the Higgs mechanism; Quantum Chromodynamics, asymptotic freedom, and quark confinement; techniques for precision calculations for the Large Hadron Collider; examples of beyond-the-Standard-Model physics, effective field theory formulation of new physics.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Electricity & Magnetism 2
catalog.description: Recommended for students who lacked or were poorly prepared in junior/senior-level physics courses. Topics: mechanics, electromagnetic fields, interaction of electromagnetic fields with matter, special relativity.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Quantum Mechanics 2
catalog.description: First course deals with basic principles and formulations of quantum mechanics, classical limit and WKB method, representations and transformations, pure and mixed states, conservation laws and symmetries, central-force problems and solutions, and approximation methods for stationary states. Second course concentrates on coupling of angular momenta, rotation matrix, time-dependent perturbation and quantum transitions, many-electron systems, and scattering theory.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Modern Electrodynamics
catalog.description: First course deals with treatment of boundary-value problems in electrostatics and magnetostatics by method of images, orthogonal function expansions, Green's functions, and conformal mapping; multipoles, dielectrics, and magnetic materials. Second course concentrates on Maxwell's equations, propagation of plane waves in various media, radiating systems, special theory of relativity, radiation by moving charges, radiation damping, and scattering and absorption of radiation by a bound system.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Adv Quantum Mechanics
catalog.description: Topics include classical fields; quantization of fields; quantum theory of radiation; relativistic quantum mechanics of spin-half particles; covariant perturbation theory; application of second quantization method to atomic physics, particle physics, statistical mechanics, and solid-state physics.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Statistic Mechanics 2
catalog.description: Topics in equilibrium areas will include a collection of specialized topics such as renormalization group theory, solution to 2D Ising model, solution to s=1/2 XY chain (Lieb-Schultz-Mattis solution); Bethe ansatz, quantum fluids, 2D systems or similar areas of broad importance; Special topics in non-equilibrium areas may include topics such as Brownian motion and Langevin equation, Fokker-Planck equations, generalized Langevin equation, Topics in nonlinear problems or similar areas of broad importance.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Introductn Math Physics 2
catalog.description: Complex variables, ordinary and partial differential equations, special functions, Fourier series and transforms, Laplace transforms, boundary value problems, Green's functions, matrices, function spaces, group theory, tensors.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Solid State Physics 2
catalog.description: Introductory graduate solid-state physics. Topics include properties of crystalline solids, reciprocal lattice, lattice vibrations, thermal properties, electronic properties, energy bands, Fermi surface, dynamics of conduction electrons, magnetic and optical properties, semiconductors, layered structures, and superconductivity.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Elemntry Particle Physics
catalog.description: Designed to acquaint students with the broad features of particle physics, serving either as an introduction to further study or as an informative overview for specialists in other fields. Complete familiarity with special relativity and quantum mechanics is assumed. Topics: introduction to families of particles; relativistic kinematics applied to reaction cross-sections and decay rates; symmetries and conservation laws, isospin, strangeness, charm, and beauty; parity and CP violation in weak interactions; quark model of hadrons; high-energy accelerators and detectors; applications of particle physics in heavy-ion collisions, astrophysics, and the early universe.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Electronics
catalog.description: Topics: Introduction of DC and AC circuit design of analysis, Thevenin and Norton theorems, diodes and applications, properties and uses of BJT and FET transistors, negative feedback, properties and uses of operational amplifiers.  Graduate Extension for 529: Additional homework problems, additional advanced questions in the exams, laboratory practical project, and presentation at the end of the semester.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Relativity and Fields 1
catalog.description: Special relativity as a geometric theory: the metric, Lorentz transformations, energy-momentum. Vectors and tensors. The Principle of of Equivalence, the metric tensor and the affine connection. General covariance and covariant differentiation. Geodesic motion. Stress-energy and the curvature tensor; Bianchi identities; Einstein Field Equation.  The Newtonian limit: precession of perihelia and other Solar System effects. Weak fields and gravitational radiation. Black holes.  Gravitational lensing. Cosmology.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Grad Physics Laboratory 2
catalog.description: Laboratory course dealing with experimental techniques, and applications to experiments in superconductivity, Josephson effect, light scattering, infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, scanning tunneling microscopy, nuclear medicine resonance, semiconductor spectroscopy, atomic and molecular spectroscopy, laser optics, and Pi-Muon scattering.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Grad Physics Laboratory 2
catalog.description: Laboratory course dealing with experimental techniques, and applications to experiments in superconductivity, Josephson effect, light scattering, infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, scanning tunneling microscopy, nuclear medicine resonance, semiconductor spectroscopy, atomic and molecular spectroscopy, laser optics, and Pi-Muon scattering.
catalog.subject: Physics

notes.note: Introduction to Nanophysics and Nanotechnology.  This course will start with basics of solid state physics and effects of confinement that underlie most nanoscale physics and techniques. Then it will cover key concepts of nanoscale microscopy and spectroscopy, quantum transport, electron spin as a qubit, Josephson effect and SQUID, MEMS/NEMS, recent developments in 2D materials, molecular and inorganic semiconductors. Ethical issues in nanotechnology and energy in the nanoscale will also be discussed. This is a 3 credit course.

catalog.title: Department Colloquium
catalog.description: Distinguished external speakers present colloquium talks every Thursday at 3:30 p.m. Registered students are expected to attend colloquia and prepare a report on one or more colloquium topics at the end of the semester.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Department Colloquium
catalog.description: Distinguished external speakers present colloquium talks every Thursday at 3:30 p.m. Registered students are expected to attend colloquia and prepare a report on one or more colloquium topics at the end of the semester.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Independent Study
catalog.description: Designed to suit the specific needs of individual students who want to study certain topics in physics at the graduate level.
catalog.subject: Physics

catalog.title: Supervised Teaching
catalog.description: Registration only by consent of the department chair. Teaching assignments within the department are delegated to each registrant. Assignment is supervised by a member of the department staff. May be taken more than once for credit.
catalog.subject: Physics
